snippet.textDisplay: Ok I get why they have this new tech in F1. But what I don’t understand is, why do people have negative cambers on their daily driver cars? snippet.textDisplay: AFAIK, toe-out is needed due to the difference in slip angle between highly loaded outside tyre, and lightly loaded inside tire.  Without toe-out, it would compromise the maximum cornering grip because the outside tire will tend to break traction first.  Ackerman geometry also gives the same benefit.
snippet.textOriginal: AFAIK, toe-out is needed due to the difference in slip angle between highly loaded outside tyre, and lightly loaded inside tire.  Without toe-out, it would compromise the maximum cornering grip because the outside tire will tend to break traction first.  Ackerman geometry also gives the same benefit.

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting that it will be banned for 2021. That could help Mercedes. Will the other teams bother spending six months researching and developing this only for a few months use? And if it wasn't banned for next year they very much all would copy it, meaning Mercedes would lose the advantage for next year.  So being banned for next year means Mercedes will get the benefit this year and then everyone will be back to square one!

snippet.textDisplay:
@THE RACE This explanation has now been *DEBUNKED* . James Allison has said in the official video explaining the 2020 car that the DAS system was created for aerodynamic purposes, NOT to reduce friction or to cool the tires.

By the way, next time when you're guessing what the teams are doing, use the word guessed instead of "explained", since that's what you are actually doing. And you won't look as bad when your "expert explanation" turns out to be wrong.
snippet.textOriginal:
@THE RACE This explanation has now been **DEBUNKED** . James Allison has said in the official video explaining the 2020 car that the DAS system was created for aerodynamic purposes, NOT to reduce friction or to cool the tires.

By the way, next time when you're guessing what the teams are doing, use the word *guessed* instead of "explained", since that's what you are actually doing. And you won't look as bad when your "expert explanation" turns out to be wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: One thing I dont think I heard them address was the increase in straight line braking ability. Not only will this help in other areas but definitely later braking. The more camber you have the more you reduce your braking distance due to tire patch contact. Think if it is used properly not only will they be faster in high speed turns but also allow them to brake later giving them better entry speeds into and out of the corner.
snippet.textOriginal: One thing I dont think I heard them address was the increase in straight line braking ability. Not only will this help in other areas but definitely later braking. The more camber you have the more you reduce your braking distance due to tire patch contact. Think if it is used properly not only will they be faster in high speed turns but also allow them to brake later giving them better entry speeds into and out of the corner.

snippet.textDisplay: Everyone is talking about tire contact with the tarmac.  How about the aero gains from changing the airflow around the tires based on their attack angle with the air. Air being a fluid, change the angle change the flow. Will the air stall at different parts giving you a speed advantage of less drag? Or will the airflow change which parts of the aero bits are working when. I think there are more effects then just tire wear and heat. Great engineering. Early days of this system. Thank you for making the video. Enjoyed the presentation. Oh side thought. If this does change the airflow over the car. The system is operated by the driver, this becomes a movable aero dynamic device. Does D.A.S.fall under movable aero, which I think is illegal per the regulations? Yes I know the wheels already rotate. And the rotating wheels/tires are excluded. But changing the attack angle by the driver then becomes a aero advantage changed by the driver while driving. Food for thought.
snippet.textOriginal: Everyone is talking about tire contact with the tarmac.  How about the aero gains from changing the airflow around the tires based on their attack angle with the air. Air being a fluid, change the angle change the flow. Will the air stall at different parts giving you a speed advantage of less drag? Or will the airflow change which parts of the aero bits are working when. I think there are more effects then just tire wear and heat. Great engineering. Early days of this system. Thank you for making the video. Enjoyed the presentation. Oh side thought. If this does change the airflow over the car. The system is operated by the driver, this becomes a movable aero dynamic device. Does D.A.S.fall under movable aero, which I think is illegal per the regulations? Yes I know the wheels already rotate. And the rotating wheels/tires are excluded. But changing the attack angle by the driver then becomes a aero advantage changed by the driver while driving. Food for thought.

snippet.textDisplay: The steering and suspension are two components of the same mechanism.  Whats not steering is a suspension setting.  Steering is turning the car.  No one ever has referred to it as otherwise.  If a driver manipulates anything in the cockpit, including the steering column, and the car goes straight, it is changing the suspension.  Big money mercedes and F1 politics.  Enjoy the novelty folks, its illegal next year.
snippet.textOriginal: The steering and suspension are two components of the same mechanism.  Whats not steering is a suspension setting.  Steering is turning the car.  No one ever has referred to it as otherwise.  If a driver manipulates anything in the cockpit, including the steering column, and the car goes straight, it is changing the suspension.  Big money mercedes and F1 politics.  Enjoy the novelty folks, its illegal next year.

snippet.textDisplay: there has to be an aero benefit to this as well...toe out creates so much more bad aero wash on the body of the car. also would allow more toe out to be set into the steering knowing that it can be taken out down the straights or fine turned between corners.(you could have a digital sensor telling the driver how much toe is being used at any point in time).  i would also think that others would be able to copy this with out to much trouble as they could add something run it in the car during friday practise and if its not working perfectly just not allow the drives to use it during the race.

snippet.textDisplay:
2:23 Diagram with animation is SO MUCH EASIER TO UNDERSTAND than the horribly nuanced, jargon filled way it has to be explained. It's actually such a simple, obvious, gorgeous bit of design that I'm amazed nobody has tried it before.

snippet.textDisplay: Many modern street cars, including performance and economy, come factory with the so called Dual Axis Steering. They are nothing new or special. They are just a function of the geometry of the suspension design. The fact that people give the system a fancy name makes it seem high tech when it really isn't.
snippet.textOriginal: Many modern street cars, including performance and economy, come factory with the so called Dual Axis Steering. They are nothing new or special. They are just a function of the geometry of the suspension design. The fact that people give the system a fancy name makes it seem high tech when it really isn't.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem would be better solved if the lower swing arm was shortened instead of the steering tie rods lengthened.
Lengthening the tie rods eliminates toe out and scrubbing but the tire is still running on its inner edge because of the camber.
If you shorten the lower swingarm you kill 2 birds with one stone. You toe in the front wheels AND you straighten up the camber.
BUT that would be considered a SUSPENSION ADJUSTMENT and therefore illegal.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem would be better solved if the lower swing arm was shortened instead of the steering tie rods lengthened.
Lengthening the tie rods eliminates toe out and scrubbing but the tire is still running on its inner edge because of the camber.
If you shorten the lower swingarm you kill 2 birds with one stone. You toe in the front wheels AND you straighten up the camber.
BUT that would be considered a SUSPENSION ADJUSTMENT and therefore illegal.

snippet.textDisplay: No doubt it changes toe but not from toe out to less toe or zero toe as said. That would not be visible by eye. Normaly this is needed in long straits and cold or wet conditions.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't think that this system is legal. Toe angle of tyres are a part of the suspension geometry and parc ferme regulations explicitly state that the suspension gepmetry can't be changed or worked on after the car leaves the garage for qualifying and the race.

snippet.textDisplay:
Of the top of my head, it is cheating. You can't change the suspension settings while in motion.


10.2.2 Any powered device which is capable of altering the configuration or affecting the
performance of any part of any suspension system is forbidden.
10.2.3 No adjustment may be made to any suspension system while the car is in motion.



"Any" suspension system. So how does changing the toe not affect other suspension components?
The castor will mean that the toe will affect 'other' suspension systems.


We shall see
snippet.textOriginal:
Of the top of my head, it is cheating. You can't change the suspension settings while in motion.


10.2.2 Any powered device which is capable of altering the configuration or affecting the
performance of any part of any suspension system is forbidden.
10.2.3 No adjustment may be made to any suspension system while the car is in motion.



"Any" suspension system. So how does changing the toe not affect other suspension components?
The castor will mean that the toe will affect 'other' suspension systems.


We shall see

snippet.textDisplay: I really do not understand the 'difficult' to use assumptions.  Considering the natural flow of the G forces under acceleration and breaking, the process/movements involved to manage the DAS system seem rather natural and intuitive tbh, and likely to applied by drivers pretty subconsciously with very little actual effort of adjustment to style/driving method required at all.  To me, that's the most genius part of whole design, how the control system just seems to flow with what the car and driver are experiencing on track at the time anyway.
snippet.textOriginal: I really do not understand the 'difficult' to use assumptions.  Considering the natural flow of the G forces under acceleration and breaking, the process/movements involved to manage the DAS system seem rather natural and intuitive tbh, and likely to applied by drivers pretty subconsciously with very little actual effort of adjustment to style/driving method required at all.  To me, that's the most genius part of whole design, how the control system just seems to flow with what the car and driver are experiencing on track at the time anyway.

snippet.textDisplay:
Leave it to ze Germans to come up with a brilliant, seemingly obvious innovation that cascades into a bunch of benefits.

In one simple change they’ve made it so they have optimal toe in for cornering and straight line performance, less tire wear (which will also improve braking) and arguably better aero angles going into and coming out of corners and most likely better fuel economy from lack of tire friction. It’s minute, but all this will add up over the course of each race, and probably much more depending on each track (once they dial it in).

I imagine they’ll cater the toe angles more or less aggressive depending on how twisty each track is, so it’s almost a permanent advantage (and I’d bet the farm that other top teams are gonna be pulling all nighters to try an duplicate it).

This’ll be yet another year of Merc dominance, and while it does get tiring to see the same team win handily every year, it’s stuff like this that makes you realize they deserve it. One thing you can’t say about Mercedes is that they rest on their laurels.
snippet.textOriginal:
Leave it to ze Germans to come up with a brilliant, seemingly obvious innovation that cascades into a bunch of benefits.

In one simple change they’ve made it so they have optimal toe in for cornering and straight line performance, less tire wear (which will also improve braking) and arguably better aero angles going into and coming out of corners and most likely better fuel economy from lack of tire friction. It’s minute, but all this will add up over the course of each race, and probably much more depending on each track (once they dial it in).

I imagine they’ll cater the toe angles more or less aggressive depending on how twisty each track is, so it’s almost a permanent advantage (and I’d bet the farm that other top teams are gonna be pulling all nighters to try an duplicate it).

This’ll be yet another year of Merc dominance, and while it does get tiring to see the same team win handily every year, it’s stuff like this that makes you realize they deserve it. One thing you can’t say about Mercedes is that they rest on their laurels.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder if it is significant that it changes toe-in/out and not camber?

Toe is inarguably in the plane of steering, so you are clearly steering, whereas if it changed camber you would be introducing a suspension change, altering set-up.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder if it is significant that it changes toe-in/out and not camber?

Toe is inarguably in the plane of steering, so you are clearly steering, whereas if it changed camber you would be introducing a suspension change, altering set-up.

snippet.textDisplay: so depending on the race track and the time and effort merc is willing to put into it, will matter how effective this is.  I doubt it will be useful at a few of the street races (singapore, monico) as there is not much  to gain on a straight vrs the corners,  on the important tracks for it merc now needs to do 2 times their homework.  Assuming 2 positions/track for the system ( forward and back)  then how much do you compromise for a given  position for a given track.  And how much adjustment can you get in total?    Wile a fun tool i doubt every team has the capability to manage it correctly even if they implement it.
